author: By German Lopez
title: Cutting Red Tape
description: We’re covering a major policy challenge for Democrats.
content: President Trump has spent the first few weeks of his second term bulldozing through the federal bureaucracy. He says that the government and its rules are inefficient and, during his first term, got in the way of executing his agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: The New York Times Wins 3 Polk Awards
description: The Times was honored for an investigation into extremism in Israel, coverage of the civil war in Sudan and a narrative about a Russian soldier who defected from the war in Ukraine.
content: Journalists from The New York Times, The New Yorker and ProPublica were among the winners of the George Polk Awards, which were announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker, Maureen Farrell and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: As Wall Street Chases Profits, Fire Departments Have Paid the Price
description: Fire engine manufacturing is now largely controlled by three companies. Around the country, prices have soared, and orders can take years to fulfill.
content: Desperate to gain control of flames that were raging through Pacific Palisades last month, the Los Angeles Fire Department issued an urgent call for any available personnel to report for possible deployment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams, Anton Troianovski, Rob Szypko, Alex Stern, Mooj Zadie, Maria Byrne, Patricia Willens, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker and Chris Wood
title: Trump Shocks Europe
description: President Trump’s embrace of Russia is a major setback for the relationship between Europe and the U.S.
content: A few days ago, the Trump administration began blowing up America’s existing approach to ending the war in Europe by embracing Russia and snubbing Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Celebrates 50 Years With Star-Studded Prime-Time Special
description: Stage and audience alike at Studio 8H were packed with cast, alumni and other celebrities in a night that was in turns sweet and self-satirizing.
content: After a half-century of comedy and music (and what at times felt like an equal amount of buildup and hype), how do you at last kick off a prime-time 50th anniversary special for “Saturday Night Live”? Calmly and serenely, it turns out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Southwest Airlines Plans to Cut 15% of Corporate Work Force
description: The company said the cuts, the first round of broad layoffs in the airline’s 53-year history, would affect mostly corporate employees.
content: Southwest Airlines on Monday announced plans to cut 1,750 jobs, the first broad layoffs in the airline’s 53-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim, Stephanie Saul and Winnie Hu
title: Thousands Gather on Presidents’ Day to Call Trump a Tyrant
description: Protesters opposing broad swaths of President Trump’s agenda took the streets across the country, including outside the U.S. Capitol.
content: Thousands of protesters opposing broad swaths of President Trump’s agenda took to the streets across the United States on Monday, calling Mr. Trump a “king” on Presidents’ Day for his efforts to terminate thousands of federal workers and to fire prosecutors and independent watchdogs within the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Feb. 17, 2025
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 17, 2025.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: How Can It End? A Step-by-Step Guide to a Possible Ukraine Deal.
description: Balancing Ukraine’s sovereignty with Russia’s demand for its own “security guarantees” promises to be the hardest part of any negotiation. But experts see possible compromises.
content: President Trump says he wants to “make a deal” to “STOP this ridiculous war” in Ukraine. His call with President Vladimir V. Putin, and a meeting expected this week between U.S. and Russian officials in Saudi Arabia, have raised expectations that negotiations could end three years of fighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Euan Ward
title: Israel Says It Will Keep Troops ‘Temporarily’ in 5 Points in Lebanon
description: The announcement raised the specter of renewed fighting in southern Lebanon between Israel and Hezbollah, the Lebanese militia.
content: The Israeli military said on Monday that it will keep forces in five locations in southern Lebanon after a deadline for its full withdrawal lapses on Tuesday. The announcement raised fears of a resurgence in violence in southern Lebanon between Israel and Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefano Montali
title: Compliments Are His Punchline
description: Milo McCabe, a comedian known for complimenting strangers through his character Troy Hawke, is proof that kindness never goes out of style.
content: Troy Hawke is known to be quick-witted and kind. A man of manners. A connoisseur of charm. A hero for the social-media age. His superpower? Creating moments of unexpected delight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Why Don’t People Dress Up to Go Out Anymore?
description: The informality that dominates in most public spaces today has been brewing for quite some time, our critic explains, and speaks to a broader cultural shift.
content: It’s not just at restaurants that the dress code has become more relaxed; it’s pretty much everywhere. People don’t dress up for the theater, the opera, work or travel. Sometimes airports look more like giant sleepover parties than transportation hubs. And it’s been that way for some time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Washington Post Cancels Ad From Groups Calling for Trump to Fire Musk
description: The newspaper told Common Cause, an advocacy group, that it was pulling its special ad, which would have covered the front and back pages of some Tuesday editions.
content: An advertisement that was set to run in some editions of The Washington Post on Tuesday calling for Elon Musk to be fired from his role in government was abruptly canceled, according to one of the advocacy groups that had ordered the ad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadie Stein
title: The Forgotten Writers Who Influenced Jane Austen
description: In “Jane Austen’s Bookshelf,” a rare-book collector sets out to “investigate” a group of overlooked female writers.
content: It is a truth universally acknowledged (at least in publishing) that books about books sell well, and, judging by their profusion, that includes those devoted to Jane Austen Inc.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope to Stay in Hospital to Address ‘Complex’ Clinical Issue, Vatican Says
description: Pope Francis was admitted on Friday with a respiratory infection. The announcement on Monday did not provide further detail, but raised fresh concerns about the pontiff’s health.
content: Pope Francis will remain in a Rome hospital after being admitted late last week following a series of tests that indicated a “complex clinical picture,” the Vatican said on Monday, raising fresh concerns about the 88-year-old pontiff’s health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: Watching ‘Shoah’ in Berlin, 80 Years After Auschwitz
description: A commemorative screening of the monumental documentary came as some artists are questioning whether Germany’s Holocaust remembrance culture stifles free speech.
content: On the first Sunday of this year’s Berlin International Film Festival, Claude Lanzmann’s “Shoah” (1985) — a nine-and-a-half-hour documentary about the Holocaust — screened to a nearly full house in the auditorium of the city’s Academy of Arts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Moises Velasquez-Manoff
title: What to Know About Buprenorphine, a Proven Treatment for Opioid Addiction
description: This medicine may be one of the best tools doctors have to fight the fentanyl crisis.
content: When President Trump announced plans to impose tariffs on Mexico and Canada, one of his stated rationales was to force those countries to curb the flow of fentanyl into the United States. In fiscal year 2024, United States Customs and Border Protection seized nearly 22,000 pounds of pills, powders and other products containing fentanyl, down from 27,000 pounds in the previous fiscal year. More than 105,000 people died from overdoses, three-quarters of them from fentanyl and other opioids, in 2023. It doesn’t take much illicit fentanyl — said to be about 50 times as powerful as heroin and 100 times as powerful as morphine — to cause a fatal overdose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Education Dept. Gives Schools Two Weeks to Eliminate Race-Based Programs
description: The department’s Office for Civil Rights warned that it would penalize schools that consider race in scholarships, hiring and an array of other activities.
content: The Education Department warned schools in a letter on Friday that they risked losing federal funding if they continued to take race into account when making scholarship or hiring decisions, or so much as nodded to race in “all other aspects of student, academic and campus life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: It’s Now Up to the Judge Whether to Drop Charges in Adams Case
description: Judge Dale E. Ho of Federal District Court in Manhattan has yet to respond to the government’s request to dismiss the federal corruption case against Mayor Eric Adams.
content: The Manhattan judge overseeing the federal corruption case against Mayor Eric Adams will be in the spotlight this week after a standoff between federal prosecutors and the Justice Department over a directive to drop the charges against the mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Canada as the 51st State? In Electoral Terms, Trump’s Idea Favors Democrats.
description: Bringing Canada into the United States, however farcical the prospect may seem, would alter the political map in a way likely to cost Republicans.
content: As President Trump looks north and repeatedly presses his case to absorb Canada as the “51st state,” politically minded Democrats who are otherwise outraged by almost everything else about his agenda find themselves contemplating a potential electoral boon should it ever happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Why Everyone Is Still Talking About ‘Paddington 2’
description: With the third movie now in theaters, let’s look at how the 2018 film became a sleeper hit, thanks to Hugh Grant’s villain and its showstopping end credits.
content: “Paddington 2 is the greatest film ever made,” one user posted on X in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Let’s Argue About Our Phones (and Tech in General)
description: Phones, smart and dumb, and tech in general. Also: Calling people stupid; Elon Musk and “state capture”; the autocrats’ playbook.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Starmer Offers to Send U.K. Peacekeeping Troops to Ukraine
description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer said for the first time on Sunday that he was “ready and willing” to deploy troops to help guarantee Ukraine’s security.
content: Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Sunday offered British troops to help guarantee Ukraine’s security as part of any peace deal, as he and other European leaders convened to coordinate a response to President Trump’s talks with Russia about ending the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
title: Zakia Jafri, Who Sought Justice for Victims of Indian Riots, Dies at 86
description: For two decades, she waged a legal battle against government officials in India after her husband was brutally killed in Gujarat in 2002.
content: Zakia Jafri, who turned her personal loss into an uphill campaign for justice after her husband, Ehsan Jafri, was brutally murdered during sectarian riots in the Indian state of Gujarat in 2002, died on Feb. 2 at her daughter’s home in Ahmedabad, India. She was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison Sweet Grant
title: There’s One Lie I Will Never Tell My Children
description: It’s “This won’t hurt.”
content: Parents who claim to never lie to their children are liars. It begins with Santa Claus and the Tooth Fairy. Then it’s yes, all kindergartners go to bed at 7 o’clock and no, the chickens on the farm and the chicken on your plate are not the same kind of chicken. Most of these untruths are harmless — white lies, we call them. But there are some lies we tell as parents, however well intentioned, that do more harm than good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein, Jeffery C. Mays and Benjamin Oreskes
title: Hochul to Discuss Adams’s Future as Pressure Mounts for His Resignation
description: Adrienne Adams, the speaker of the New York City Council, said on Monday that Mayor Eric Adams should step aside.
content: Adrienne Adams, the speaker of the New York City Council and one of Mayor Eric Adams’s principal partners in government, said on Monday that the mayor should resign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim
title: Trump Fired, Then Unfired, National Nuclear Security Administration Employees. What Were Their Jobs?
description: The administration asked some of the agency’s workers, who were part of last week’s massive layoffs across the federal government, to come back.
content: When termination letters were sent to employees across the federal government last week, the Trump administration affected an agency charged with the readiness of America’s nuclear arsenal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart Emmrich and Jake Naughton
title: The Timeless Appeal of Puerto Vallarta
description: In the 1960s, Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor hid away in what was a bucolic town on the Pacific Coast of Mexico. Decades later, a writer discovered why.
content: I first traveled to the Mexican resort town of Puerto Vallarta because of a decades-old, black-and-white movie. On a frigid winter night, as I was flipping channels in my Manhattan apartment, I stumbled across a showing of “The Night of the Iguana” on Turner Classic Movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Zarroli
title: One Fix for Ailing Movie Theaters? Becoming Nonprofits.
description: As more local movie houses close, residents in smaller towns are forming nonprofits to buy and operate them.
content: Nicki Wilson was shocked when her local newspaper reported in March 2023 that the Triplex Theater, an independent four-screen movie house in Great Barrington, Mass., was shutting down after almost three decades in business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: An Invisible Medical Shortage: Oxygen
description: Oxygen is vital to many medical procedures. But a safe, affordable supply is severely lacking around the world, according to a new report.
content: At the height of the Covid-19 pandemic, millions of people in poor nations died literally gasping for breath, even in hospitals. What they lacked was medical oxygen, which is in short supply in much of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Ismaeel Naar
title: Rubio Meets Saudi Crown Prince for Talks on Gaza and Ukraine
description: Marco Rubio’s visit to Riyadh, his first as secretary of state, came amid uncertainty about the future of Gaza and Ukraine and criticism of unilateral U.S. moves over the wars in both places.
content: The de facto leader of Saudi Arabia, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, met on Monday with three senior members of the Trump administration, including Secretary of State Marco Rubio, who were visiting the kingdom to discuss the future of both Gaza and Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Praise Song for a False Spring
description: Any sign that nature is working as it ought to reminds me to keep faith in the future.
content: Last month, while the rest of the world was burning up during the hottest January on record, it was unseasonably cold here in Middle Tennessee. I walked around my yard exulting at the sharpness in the air, at the cold blue of the daytime sky and the starry brightness at night. After a fall that lingered and lingered, winter was here at last. A real winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Achy Obejas
title: Finally, at 59, a Place of Her Own
description: A filmmaker in Oakland, Calif., had always lived with her family, her ex-husband, son or roommates. A friend helped her find her own place when she needed it most.
content: When Dawn Valadez stepped into her new two-story loft in Oakland’s Jingletown neighborhood, a realization struck her with quiet force: For the first time in her 59 years, she would be living alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘The White Lotus’ Season 3 Premiere Recap: Thai Up
description: The premiere of the new season of the HBO anthology drama, set in Thailand, suggests that Mike White’s formula retains plenty of pop.
content: Take a moment. Focus on your breathing. Calm your mind. Let the sounds of the external world fade away. Did you just hear gunshots? Ignore them. Embrace the now. Find in your minds what is timeless. Pay no attention to the corpse floating by you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Bromley
title: A South Korean Filmmaker’s Early Fiction Holds a Mirror to His Past
description: Set in 1980s South Korea, Lee Chang-dong’s book “Snowy Day and Other Stories” hangs in the shadow of the violent Gwangju massacre.
content: In the first minutes of “Burning,” a 2018 movie by the South Korean filmmaker Lee Chang-dong, the voice of President Trump rings out from a TV newscast, setting the stage for the ensuing story of a young farmer’s son whose life is determined more by a political order being constructed far out of his sight than by the personal choices in front of him. “Burning” perfectly dramatizes the bewildering situation of young people living like interlopers in a world that’s handed over its keys to an elusive class of financial elites. Jong-su knows he is being shut out, but how and by whom he cannot fully answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Steven Erlanger
title: European Leaders Meet in Paris as U.S. Pushes Ahead With Ukraine Plan
description: The hastily called gathering was part of a flurry of diplomacy expected to center on Ukraine this week as Trump officials prepare to start talks with Russia on their own.
content: The leaders of many of Europe’s biggest countries came to Paris on Monday in an effort to forge a strategy for their own security, as President Trump’s envoys prepared for talks with Russia over ending the war in Ukraine without them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4,400 Rentals in Los Angeles
description: A Craftsman house near Culver City, a 1970s condo in West Hollywood and a 1920s bungalow in Hollywood.
content: To provide a resource for those displaced by the Los Angeles fires, this edition of “What You Get” focuses on rentals rather than for-sale properties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meaghan Tobin and Jin Yu Young
title: South Korea Bans Downloads of DeepSeek, the Chinese A.I. App
description: Regulators said they would suspend the app until they could be sure it complied with the country’s data protection laws.
content: The South Korean government said on Monday that it had temporarily suspended new downloads of an artificial intelligence chatbot made by DeepSeek, the Chinese company that has sent shock waves through the tech world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: China’s Leader Embraces Business, Even Jack Ma. But Will It Be Enough?
description: The once-sidelined Alibaba founder was among the executives who met with Xi Jinping, in what was seen as a show of support for private enterprise by Beijing.
content: When Beijing sidelined Jack Ma, China’s most prominent entrepreneur, by slamming the brakes on his business in 2020, it sent an unmistakable message that no company was above the Chinese Communist Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Sheet-Pan Chicken, but Make It Ottolenghi
description: Soft potatoes, silky-sweet peppers and good ol’ chickpeas line the pan beneath the chicken, primed to absorb all the fragrant, meaty juices.
content: A tray bake in the U.K. is what we in North America would call a sheet-pan dinner. I like the British term, a more succinct and, I think, euphonious name for an easy one-pan meal. You probably know I’m a fan of those, since I write about them pretty much every chance I get. Well, this week I’ve got a doozy for you from none other than Yotam Ottolenghi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Killing of Transgender Man Is Not Ruled a Hate Crime, Investigators Say
description: Law enforcement officials in upstate New York say that the torture and killing of Sam Nordquist, 24, did not appear to be a hate crime.
content: Investigators have found no evidence that the torture and killing of a transgender man whose remains were found in a field in upstate New York last week was a hate crime, law enforcement officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naguel Rivero and Ian Bradley
title: So Long, Winter Whites. Red and Black Are the Colors of the Season.
description: Spring fashion’s wild new shapes and bold adornments extend from head to toe in striking hues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren
title: Republicans Want Lower Taxes. The Hard Part Is Choosing What to Cut.
description: House Republicans are preparing to adopt a plan that puts a $4.5 trillion limit on the size of the tax cut, but even that will not be enough for some of President Trump’s promises.
content: Since their party swept to power, Republicans have entertained visions of an all-inclusive tax cut — one that could permanently lower rates for individuals, shower corporations with new incentives and deliver President Trump’s sprawling suite of campaign promises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: A diplomatic scramble over Ukraine.
content: As American officials prepare for talks with Russia this week about ending the war in Ukraine, European leaders will convene their own emergency meeting today in Paris. They hope to coordinate a response to President Trump’s opening of negotiations with Moscow, which have no apparent role for Europe — or for Ukraine itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: South African Imam and Gay Rights Advocate Is Shot Dead
description: Muhsin Hendricks was credited by some as being the world’s first openly gay imam and helped Muslims reconcile their faith with their sexual orientation.
content: A South African imam who devoted his life to promoting gay rights and tolerance for L.G.B.T.Q. Muslims was shot and killed in the coastal city of Gqeberha on Saturday, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: ‘Sanctuary Always Needed’: A Home for Dance Risk-Takers Turns 50
description: Danspace in Manhattan celebrates its anniversary with a festival that honors artistic transmission, passing down and reinventing older works.
content: On a recent evening in the East Village, the dancers Kris Lee and AJ Wilmore careened across a studio, grappling and colliding with each other. Their limbs butted and interlocked; one dancer’s head burrowed into the other’s stomach. Sometimes what looked like fighting morphed into play, or the two ambled off on their own before crashing back together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,340
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Feb. 18, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: California’s Push for Electric Trucks Sputters Under Trump
description: The state will no longer require some truckers to shift away from diesel semis but hopes that subsidies can keep dreams of pollution-free big rigs alive.
content: President Trump’s policies could threaten many big green energy projects in the coming years, but his election has already dealt a big blow to an ambitious California effort to replace thousands of diesel-fueled trucks with battery-powered semis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard L. Revesz
title: It’s the Little Changes That Can Undermine Government
description: The Trump administration is quietly upending government rules and policies.
content: There are plenty of ways to upend the workings of the federal government. There is the blunt-force approach: firing people, cutting budgets, eliminating agencies. That is what the Trump administration has been doing, and it has been generating plenty of headlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Jones
title: At 30, the Jazz Gallery Remains a Force. Rio Sakairi Is Its Heart.
description: The nonprofit venue’s artistic director has long booked and guided artists from her gut.
content: Rio Sakairi patted around inside her purse and retrieved a key that unlocks the elevator at 1158 Broadway. Exiting on the fifth floor, she glanced toward the black door leading to the performance space in Manhattan’s Flatiron neighborhood, where the Jazz Gallery has made its home since 2012. The saxophonist Ben Wendel’s four-vibraphone band was about to perform on this January night: “This one you want to hear from the beginning,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javid Ahmad
title: The U.S. Can No Longer Ignore the Threat Arising in Afghanistan
description: Engaging directly with the Taliban may be the only way to protect Americans from the jihadist threat that stirs once again in Afghanistan.
content: President Trump has promised a bold new American approach to the world. Nowhere is that more urgently needed than in Afghanistan. Not only have its Taliban rulers crushed dissent and stripped away the rights of the country’s women and girls; they have also taken Americans hostage and are allowing Afghanistan to serve as a nerve center of violent jihadist networks such as Al Qaeda. We all know what happened on Sept. 11, 2001, the last time this state of affairs existed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton and Maggie Haberman
title: With Congress Pliant, an Emboldened Trump Pushes His Business Interests
description: Norms recognized for decades in Washington by both parties no longer appear to apply to the Trump White House, former prosecutors and ethics lawyers say.
content: The Oval Office meeting convened by President Trump brought together the most important leaders in the world of professional golf: Jay Monahan, the top executive at the PGA Tour, and, via telephone, Yasir Al-Rumayyan, the chairman of the Saudi Arabia-backed league known as LIV Golf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Nothing to See Here. Everything Is Exactly as It Should Be.
description: The problem is that if we have another three years and 11 months of this, there won’t be a rule of law left in the United States.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. You may or may not be happy to hear this, but once again I feel completely nauseated by Donald Trump. That took all of four weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Paquita la del Barrio, Whose Songs Empowered Women, Dies at 77
description: In unflinching ballads that spoke of the pain men can cause women, the Mexican singer often relied on what she learned in her own relationships.
content: Paquita la del Barrio, the prolific Mexican vocalist and songwriter known for her powerful feminist ballads, died on Monday at her home in Veracruz. She was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Is Fake Meat Better for You Than Real Meat?
description: Here’s what we do — and don’t — know.
content: You’ve probably heard these two bits of nutrition advice: Eat more plants, and cut back on ultraprocessed foods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and William K. Rashbaum
title: Who Are the 4 Key Officials Leaving City Hall?
description: Four deputy mayors in the Eric Adams administration — all respected veteran public servants — are resigning.
content: On Monday, four of Mayor Eric Adams’s eight deputy mayors announced they would resign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Wallace Johnson, Lydia Polgreen and Jillian Weinberger
title: My Values ‘Can’t Be Nullified by an Executive Order’
description: A former U.S.A.I.D. worker talks with the columnist Lydia Polgreen about enduring the second Trump administration.
content: Kirk Wallace Johnson served with U.S.A.I.D. in Baghdad and Falluja. When he returned to the United States, he spent much of his career helping thousands of Iraqis and Afghans, many of whom risked their lives working with American troops, gain refugee status in the United States through the List Project. As President Trump closes the door on the American refugee program, Johnson and the Times columnist Lydia Polgreen grapple with how to live now, through Trump’s second term, in the face of a muted resistance movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Akira Davis and Hisako Ueno
title: From Japan, a Hard Lesson About a Weak Currency
description: Though it recovered in the second half of the year, Japan’s economy barely grew in 2024 as a depreciated yen fueled inflation and strained households.
content: For decades in Japan, it was accepted as gospel: A weak currency makes companies more competitive and bolsters the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Yong
title: Singapore Opposition Leader Gets Guilty Verdict but Can Run in Election
description: In a blow to the Workers’ Party, its leader, Pritam Singh, was fined for lying under oath to Parliament.
content: A Singapore court on Monday found the nation’s opposition leader guilty of lying under oath to Parliament, in a case that has riveted the country because it raised the prospect of disqualifying him from office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colby Smith
title: Can the Fed Look Past Trump’s Tariffs?
description: Top officials are grappling with how to handle potential price increases caused by the administration’s policies.
content: As President Trump’s efforts to restructure the global trade system with expansive tariffs begin to take shape, one question continues to dog officials at the Federal Reserve: How will these policies affect the central bank’s plans to lower interest rates?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur, David W. Chen and Tricia Fulks Kelley
title: ‘Here We Go Again’: Kentucky Residents Face More Destruction and Anxiety From Storms
description: The flood damage of recent days was not as catastrophic as some previous climate disasters in the state. But the rains still brought widespread havoc, and painful reminders of trauma.
content: As unrelenting rain pelted Kentucky, and as the nearby river nearby continued to rise, the two sisters — and business partners — did what they could to protect the quilt shop they own in Hazard, a town of about 5,000 people in the eastern part of the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Dana Rubinstein and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: 4 Top Officials to Resign Over Adams’s Cooperation With Trump
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul said the resignations raised “serious questions about the long-term future of this mayoral administration.” She planned to meet with elected officials to discuss “the path forward.”
content: Four top New York City officials said they would resign after the Justice Department moved to dismiss Mayor Eric Adams’s corruption case in apparent exchange for his help with President Trump’s deportation agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Tuesday Briefing: E.U. Discusses Security and Ukraine
description: Plus, the jury’s out on meat alternatives.
content: European leaders convened in Paris yesterday to discuss a coordinated response as the Trump administration prepared to start its own talks with Russia about ending the war in Ukraine. Leaders were also expected to discuss issues including military spending and how to guarantee Ukraine’s security once a permanent cease-fire or a peace deal was reached.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: ‘Suits L.A.,’ Plus 7 Things to Watch on TV This Week
description: A reboot of the popular law series airs on NBC. And the second season of the “Yellowstone” prequel “1923” returns to Paramount+.
content: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that air or stream this week, Feb. 17-23. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Western Allies Seem on Brink of Fateful Rift
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 17, 2025.
content: “For those in search of Trump’s strategy on Ukraine: Relax. There is no strategy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: They Asked for Help to Escape the Nazis. Their Pleas Went Unanswered.
description: A new book focuses on the desperate letters written by many Jews seeking refuge in the Netherlands but who were denied entry after it closed its border in 1938.
content: In late November 1938, when life for many Jews in Europe was dissolving, Jakob Aufrichtig in Paris penned a letter to the Committee for Jewish Refugees in Amsterdam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Trump’s Threats Against Canada Upend Conservative’s Playbook
description: A darling of the American right, Pierre Poilievre, the Conservative leader, is facing an electorate worried about Trump’s vow to annex Canada.
content: With his unapologetic conservatism, his vow to fix a “broken” nation, his “common sense” fight against elites and all things woke, his norm-shattering personal attacks against political rivals, his pugilistic use of demeaning nicknames and his open disdain of the news media, Pierre Poilievre, the front-runner to become Canada’s next leader, has become a darling of the American right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Mixing Favorite Styles Brings the Most Appealing Results
description: Add a touch of color to traditional décor for a welcoming living room. Look for an easy upgrade that pleases you, splurge on something beautiful, or make a statement with a one-of-a-kind object.
content: The British architectural and interior designer Ben Pentreath has amassed many fans by blending traditional English decoration with a sense of relaxed, colorful style to create rooms that feel warm and welcoming rather than staid or severe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Ed Martin, Trump Loyalist, Is Nominated as U.S. Attorney in Washington
description: The nomination of Mr. Martin, who stood in the crowd outside the Capitol on Jan. 6, is a full reversal for an office that formed the core of one of the Justice Department’s most complex investigations.
content: President Trump said on Monday that he had nominated the interim U.S. attorney for Washington, Ed Martin, a far-right election denier who sat on a board that raised cash for the Capitol rioters and pushed for their mass reprieve, to run the office on a permanent basis.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here’s What to See This Spring in New York
description: Onstage, Denzel Washington is Othello, and Paul Mescal is Stanley Kowalski as stars illuminate the theater marquees. Plus: FKA twigs takes “Eusexua” on tour. Bang on a Can, Twyla Tharp, and much more.
content: OPERATION MINCEMEAT A sneaky compassion lies at the heart of this caper of a show, a deliciously eccentric London import that won the 2024 Olivier Award for best new musical. Starring the original West End cast, it’s a riff on a bizarre true story from World War II, when British Intelligence, keen to misdirect the Germans, dressed up a dead man as a Royal Marines major, planted a fake invasion plan on him and dropped him in the sea for the enemy to find. Through June 15 at the Golden Theater. (All theater listings by LAURA COLLINS-HUGHES)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Andrew Duehren and Maggie Haberman
title: Musk Team Seeks Access to I.R.S. System With Taxpayers’ Records
description: A White House spokesman said that the initiative called the Department of Government Efficiency needed to review data to fix waste within the agency.
content: The Internal Revenue Service is preparing to give a team member working with Elon Musk’s so-called Department of Government Efficiency access to sensitive taxpayer data, people familiar with the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry J. Farrell and Abraham L. Newman
title: This Is How Trump Will Smash the Machine of U.S. Economic Power
description: Why the new Trump administration will inexorably weaken the country’s economic security.
content: Over the past two decades, America has built an unprecedented arsenal of economic security tools that have anchored U.S. foreign policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Trump Targets a Growing List of Those He Sees as Disloyal
description: In his first month in office, the president has carried out a campaign of retribution that has little analogue in history.
content: The lawyer Mark Zaid has represented a wide array of whistle-blowers, both Republicans and Democrats, during multiple administrations. But it was his involvement with the whistle-blower at the center of the first impeachment case against President Trump that drew the president’s ire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Democrats Fear They Are Missing the Moment to Remake the Party
description: As President Trump steamrolls over their priorities, Democrats say they could miss the opportunity to learn lessons from their defeat and undertake needed reform.
content: Several dozen Democratic political operatives had just gathered to discuss the party’s future at an upscale resort nestled along the Potomac River when the very first speaker unleashed a blistering address about the “hard truths” they needed to confront.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Refusing to Carry Out Trump’s Flagrantly Dishonest Orders
description: The Trump administration is trying to bake quid pro quo deal making, coercive tactics, loyalty tests and other dishonorable practices into American government.
content: President Trump’s determination to bend the American justice system to his will, combined with his broad tolerance for political corruption and his abhorrence of checks and balances on his power, slammed hard last week into the commitment to duty, honor and the rule of law shared by a group of federal prosecutors in the Southern District of New York and Washington, D.C. The confrontation between Mr. Trump’s lieutenants at the Justice Department — led by his former personal defense lawyer Emil Bove III — and Manhattan’s interim U.S. attorney, Danielle Sassoon, and her colleagues is the clearest example yet of this administration’s efforts to bake quid pro quo deal making, coercive tactics, loyalty tests and other dishonorable practices into American government and warp its long-held principle of equal justice before the law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: How a Runaway Dog Became a Hero for New Orleans
description: For months, Scrim ran wild around the city, eluding capture and developing a giant fan base. His saga has inspired tattoos, murals and Mardi Gras floats.
content: He evaded death at a shelter that needed to make room for more dogs. He was shot at — a veterinarian plucked pieces of ammunition from his flesh. He dodged a train, scampered across an interstate highway and survived on cat food left out for strays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fatima AbdulKarim and Patrick Kingsley
title: Palestinian Displacement in the West Bank Is Highest Since 1967, Experts Say
description: The Israeli military launched a wide-scale operation last month against militants in several cities in the West Bank. Now, roughly 40,000 Palestinians have fled their homes — the highest since Israel occupied the territory nearly six decades ago, according to researchers.
content: A weekslong Israeli military operation across several West Bank cities has displaced roughly 40,000 Palestinians from their homes, in what historians and researchers say is the biggest displacement of civilians in the territory since the Arab-Israeli war of 1967.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Why Is an Entire Age of American Opera Missing at the Met?
description: A concert performance of “Vanessa” freshly argued for the vitality of a work that deserves to be staged but languishes with its midcentury peers.
content: “Vanessa” had the kind of pedigree you rarely see in a world premiere at the Metropolitan Opera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: Kim Sae-ron, a Young South Korean Actress, Is Found Dead
description: The 24-year-old star, once a prolific child actor, appeared at the Cannes Film Festival and on Netflix, until a drunk-driving incident in 2022 derailed her career.
content: South Korean actress Kim Sae-ron, a former child star whose promising career suffered a setback in recent years after a drunk-driving incident, was found dead in her home on Sunday afternoon, police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Agent Orange Twisted Her Limbs. The U.S. Is Abandoning a Vow to Help.
description: Fifty years after the Vietnam War ended, President Trump’s gutting of foreign aid has halted American efforts to address a toxic legacy and build a strategic partnership.
content: Nearly 40 years after she was born with a malformed spine and misshapen limbs — most likely because her father was exposed to Agent Orange, the toxic chemical that the American military used during the Vietnam War — Nguyen Thi Ngoc Diem finally got some help from the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Will Jarvis, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Supreme Court Considers Trump’s Power, and Musk’s Team Wants Access to I.R.S. Records
description: Plus, how to remember everything.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Why Porsche Is No Longer a ‘Premium’ Sports Car in China
description: Chinese drivers are buying affordable electric vehicles loaded with new technology, a trend that is redefining high-end vehicles and hurting German automakers.
content: After decades of dominating China’s market for high-performance cars with precision engineering, German automakers are losing out to Chinese rivals that have shifted the definition of a high-end car to one that is electric, smart and affordable.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Talking While Black
description: People caught in the shift away from diversity, equity and inclusion.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Louis Pasteur’s Relentless Hunt for Germs Floating in the Air
description: In 19th-century France, the young chemist challenged the theory of spontaneous generation and discovered an invisible world of airborne microbes.
content: Louis Pasteur was at his most comfortable when working in his Paris laboratory. It was there that he had some of his greatest scientific triumphs, including experiments that helped confirm germs can cause disease. “Everything gets complicated away from the laboratory,” he once complained to a friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur and Rachel Nostrant
title: What We Know About the Storms That Keep Flooding Kentucky
description: Storms have overwhelmed the state in recent years. On top of the floods, snow is expected soon.
content: Sheets of rain drenched Kentucky in recent days, causing floods that turned roads and neighborhoods into rivers in a part of the country that has been pummeled by severe weather in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 618
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Feb. 18, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read Maria Torres-Springer’s resignation announcement to her staff.
description: Read the email that Maria Torres-Springer, the first deputy mayor of New York City, sent to her staff to tell them she was resigning from the Eric Adams administration, along with deputy mayors Meera Joshi and Anne Williams-Isom.
content: Read the email that Maria Torres-Springer, the first deputy mayor of New York City, sent to her staff to tell them she was resigning from the Eric Adams administration, along with deputy mayors Meera Joshi and Anne Williams-Isom.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Letter
description: Letter from former prosecutor
content: Letter from former prosecutor
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Delta Plane Crashes and Flips Over During Landing in Toronto
description: All 80 people on the flight from Minneapolis made it off the plane, which overturned and caught fire. At least 18 people were injured.
content: All 80 people on the flight from Minneapolis made it off the plane, which overturned and caught fire. At least 18 people were injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Paik
title: Deadly Storm Hits the South With Floods and Heavy Snow
description: Heavy snowfall made it hard to drive in Kentucky, and floods forced a town in Tennessee to evacuate.
content: Heavy snowfall made it hard to drive in Kentucky, and floods forced a town in Tennessee to evacuate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Nikolay Nikolov, Laura Salaberry and Samuel Granados
title: The Land Ukraine Could Be Forced to Give Up to End the War
description: President Trump has promised to bring a quick end to the war in Ukraine, suggesting that Russia could keep at least some of the Ukrainian territory it had captured. Andrew Kramer, the New York Times bureau chief in Kyiv, explains how this would leave Ukraine divided in two: one side with its government in Kyiv, and the other a battered Russian satellite to the east.
content: President Trump has promised to bring a quick end to the war in Ukraine, suggesting that Russia could keep at least some of the Ukrainian territory it had captured. Andrew Kramer, the New York Times bureau chief in Kyiv, explains how this would leave Ukraine divided in two: one side with its government in Kyiv, and the other a battered Russian satellite to the east.
source.name: The New York Times
